awd_titl_txt: Topics in Geometrical Dynamics and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project studies vehicle kinematics and related problems. The project focuses on a number of carefully selected concrete problems with applications in areas including pursuit problems, geometrical robotics, flotation theory, and fluid motion. The mathematical results of the research will have an impact on the study of fundamental differential equations (Hill's equation) that describe numerous natural phenomena, from planetary motion to the motion of electron. The investigator will actively involve undergraduate and graduate students in this research program.

The unifying theme of this project is the monodromy of the related continuous and discrete systems and a strong connection with finite- and infinite-dimensional completely integrable systems. In particular, the investigator will study connections of vehicle kinematics with the filament (binormal, local induction, smoke ring) equation, one of the most studied completely integrable partial differential equations of soliton type, and its discretizations. The research will contribute to the emerging areas of discrete differential geometry and discrete completely integrable systems.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported my research on dynamical systems of geometrical origin with continuous and discrete time, mostly involving the systems in which long-term behavior can be explicitly described (due to their complete integrability). The results contribute to better understanding of mechanisms of complete integrability and reveal connections between seemingly unrelated topics (e.g., the evolution of smoke rings, motion of electron in magnetic field of a special kind, and vehicle motion). My research has potential applications in geometrical optics (construction of mirrors with unusual optical properties in the framework of freeform optics). About 30 papers have been published in peer-review journals, many of them co-authored with collaborators. I made a concerted effort to disseminate my research by giving talks at national and international conferences, colloquia, and seminars. I was also actively involved in co-organizing conferences and workshops, including a topical semester “Hamiltonian Dynamics” in Fall of 2019  at the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute at Berkeley. 

During the life of this award I was advising four graduate students. Two of them graduated with PhD; they hold postdoctoral positions in mathematics. Two others continue working toward their dosctoral degrees. I was actively involved in outreach activity to popularize and promote mathematics at various levels, from middle and high school mathematical circles to undegraduate and graduate student expository talks to general public lectures. This outreach activity included co-organizing International Mathematical Summer School for Students "Modern Mathematics" and serving on Education Advisory Board of the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics at Brown University.
